The preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) represents a critical strategy for trace CO elimination in hydrogen purification, where CO adsorption and O2 activation are crucial for enhancing catalytic performance. Herein, we report a defect-engineered strategy mediated by MOF to promote CO adsorption and O2 activation. By pyrolyzing Ce-BDC MOF, we synthesized CeO2–O support with a high–density mesoporous structure and high surface area, facilitating the well-dispersion of CuₓO species and forming abundant interfacial Cu+ active sites. The well-dispersed Cu x O species enhance their interaction with CeO2–O, resulting in weakened Ce–O bonds and promoting both lattice oxygen activation and oxygen vacancy (Vo) formation for enhanced O2 activation. The optimized 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst demonstrates exceptional catalytic efficiency, achieving complete CO conversion at a comparatively low temperature (T100 % = 115 °C), coupled with broad temperature window applicability and outstanding stability over multiple cycles. This work establishes a MOF-guided paradigm for engineering multifunctional catalytic sites, offering a generalizable approach to design high-performance oxide catalysts for hydrogen purification and beyond. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO adsorption O2 activation Synergistic effect MOF CO–PROX Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a zero-emission energy vector, hydrogen presents considerable promise for utilization in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs), positioning itself at the forefront of sustainable power technologies [1,2]. However, trace amounts of CO (approximately 0.2 − 2 %) are inevitably present during hydrogen production [3]. These CO molecules severely poison the Pt–based anode catalysts in PEMFCs, significantly reducing their performance and service life [4]. CO preferential oxidation (CO–PROX) reaction, which can selectively oxidize CO to CO2 without affecting hydrogen concentration, has emerged as one of the most promising CO removal technologies [5]. Engineering effective CO-PROX catalysts is therefore crucial for advancing fuel cell technology toward commercial viability. Within the category of non-noble catalysts, Cu x O–CeO2 has emerged as a promising and cost-effective alternative to precious metal catalysts [6–10]. The Cu x O–CeO2 catalytic systems function through the Mars–Van Krevelen (MvK) pathway, wherein the CO oxidation kinetics are controlled by two primary rate-determining steps: (i) CO adsorption on Cu⁺ sites and (ii) O2 activation at oxygen vacancies (Vo) [11,12]. Recent advances focus on nano-structuring strategies to enhance Cu⁺ dispersion and Vo density, such as core-shell architectures [13] or facet-engineered CeO2 supports [5]. For instance, our previous work demonstrated that CeO2 exposing {100}/{111} facets stabilizes Cu x O clusters, achieving nearly 100 % CO conversion at 95 °C [5]. Nevertheless, such approaches require precise crystallographic control and complex surface modifications, hindering scalable synthesis. Therefore, from a practical catalytic perspective, developing a facile approach to synthesize novel materials with highly dispersed Cu x O species that synergistically enhance both CO adsorption and O2 activation is critical for advancing CO-PROX catalysis. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), an innovative type of crystalline porous material formed by metal ions and organic ligands, are increasingly acknowledged as highly effective sacrificial templates for producing a variety of nanomaterials [14,15]. By carefully selecting reactants and optimizing reaction conditions, MOF–derived nanomaterials can be readily synthesized with tailored compositions and morphologies. These materials retain the intrinsic features of MOFs, such as large specific surface areas and well–developed porosity, which facilitate the dispersion of active species, thereby promoting reactant molecule adsorption. Furthermore, the abundant Vo in MOF–derived nanomaterials provide additional adsorption sites, promoting molecular O2 activation [16]. Thus, motivated by these considerations, employing MOF–derived CeO2 nanomaterials as supports for constructing Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts with highly dispersed Cu x O species offers a promising strategy to simultaneously enhance CO adsorption and O2 activation, overcoming a key challenge in the CO–PROX reaction. Herein, we report a MOF-mediated dual-optimization strategy to synthesize octahedral Cu x O/CeO2–O catalysts with synergistic Cu⁺-Vo sites. By pyrolyzing Ce–BDC MOFs, we obtained CeO2–O support exhibited a high–density mesoporous structure, which promotes the distribution of Cu x O species and generating numerous Cu+ active sites. The finely distributed Cu x O species strengthen the interaction between Cu x O and CeO2, creating additional more Vo sites and promoting molecular oxygen activation. When applied to the CO–PROX reaction, the octahedral 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst exhibits outstanding catalytic activity at low temperatures, spanning a wide operational temperature range of 115−215 °C. The enhanced activity of 15Cu x O/CeO2 O was ascribed to the cooperative interplay of finely distributed Cu+ species, abundant Vo sites, and optimized oxygen mobility. This work underscores the potential of MOF-derived defect engineering in designing high-performance Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts for hydrogen purification, providing insights into the role of interfacial interactions in redox catalysis. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Materials Ammonium cerium (IV) nitrate (Ce(NH4)2·(NO3)6, ≥99.99 %), copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 98.0–102.0 %), 1,4–benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 98.0 %) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 96.0 %) were obtained from Tianjin FengChuan Chemical Research Institute (Tianjin, China). Formic acid (FA, reagent grade, ≥95 %), N,N–dimethylformamide (DMF, ≥99 %) and cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.5 wt %) were procured from Sigma–Aldrich. All materials were applied in their original form with no additional purification procedures. 2.2 Synthesis of an octahedral porous CeO2 support The synthesis procedure of the Ce–BDC MOFs precursor is described as follows. Initially, 35.4 mg of H2BDC was solubilized in a solution composed of 3 mL DMF and FA, with a DMF to FA volume ratio of 4:1. Following sonication, 1 mL of Ce(NH4)2·(NO3)6 solution at a concentration of 0.3 mol/L was incrementally introduced into the preceding solution. The resultant mixture was then sealed in a vial and subjected to a reaction at 60 °C for 2 h. The resulting Ce-BDC MOFs precursor was collected via centrifugation, subjected to triple washing cycles with DMF followed by acetone, and then thermally treated in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h. Following this drying process, the obtained precipitate was thermally decomposed through calcination under atmospheric conditions at 400 °C with a 2 h dwell time, producing octahedral porous CeO2 support, which was labeled as CeO2 O. For comparison, traditional CeO2 support (denoted as CeO2–C) were synthesized via a conventional precipitation method. Initially, a precise mass of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was completely dissolved in 100 mL of ultrapure water. Subsequently, the pH of the product solution was finetuned to the targeted value by slowly incorporating a NaOH solution while maintaining continuous stirring for 2 h. Following this, the precipitated product was isolated by centrifugation, meticulously rinsed with ethyl alcohol and deionized water, and subsequently dried in an oven. The dried powders underwent thermal treatment at 400 °C within a muffle furnace for a span of 2 h, resulting in the formation of the CeO2–C support. 2.3 Synthesis of CuxO/CeO2 catalysts The CuxO/CeO2 catalysts were synthesized via a straightforward impregnation method. Initially, an appropriate amount of CeO2–O and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was solubilized in ethanol solution, followed by ultrasonic treatment for 30 min and subsequent aging overnight. The obtained powder was dried at 60 °C and subsequently subjected to calcination at 400 °C for a duration of 2 h, resulting in the synthesis of the samples labeled as yCu x O/CeO2–O (where y represents the CuO loading amount). For comparative analysis, a control sample (yCu x O/CeO2–C) was prepared using an analogous approach, replacing CeO2–O with the conventional CeO2–C support. 2.4 Characterization and catalysis test Detailed methodologies for structural characterization and catalytic performance evaluation of the synthesized samples are provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological, structural and textural properties of CuxO/CeO2 samples A diagrammatic illustration of the preparation method for defect-abundant CeO2 support is presented in Fig. 1 a. Initially, the octahedral Ce–BDC MOF precursor was prepared via a hydrothermal method using a solution comprising Ce4+, DMF, and H2BDC, and it was subsequently calcined in an air atmosphere to yield the defective CeO2 support. The XRD pattern displayed in Fig. S1a exhibits distinctive diffraction signals in the 5–10° region attributable to the [Ce6O4(OH)4]12+ cluster, indicating the effective synthesis of the Ce–BDC MOF precursor [17]. In addition, the as–synthesized Ce–BDC MOF precursor could be completely decomposed at approximately 350 °C (Fig. S1b). Therefore, to maintain the integrity of the framework architecture, the Ce-MOF precursor underwent thermal treatment at 400 °C in ambient air conditions, yielding the CeO2 support. TEM measurements were employed to examine the morphological properties and structural details of the obtained Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 1 b, the Ce-BDC MOFs precursor displays octahedral-shaped crystals with dimensions around 200 nm. Following calcination in air, the resulting CeO2–O retains its octahedral morphology (Fig. 1 c). The surface of the CeO2–O support notably demonstrates an abundance of nanoporous features, which should facilitate improved dispersion of Cu x O species. Conversely, the CeO2 C support fabricated using the conventional NaOH precipitation approach reveals a bulk structural arrangement characterized by significant particle aggregation (Fig. S3). After loading with Cu x O species, the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst retains its octahedral morphology (Fig. 1 d). Analysis of the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) data (Fig. 1 e) substantiates the dual presence of CeO2 and CuO crystallographic structures [13]. The measured lattice fringe of 0.27 nm observed in the HRTEM image can be attributed to the (110) crystal planes of CuO (Fig. 1 f) [18]. Typical surface defects, such as sags (dark pits indicated by the arrow) and irregularities, were observed, which are likely associated with substitutional Ce3+ cations and oxygen vacancies (Fig. 1) [19]. These defects not only reflect the presence of structural imperfections but also may contribute to enhanced electron mobility and surface reactivity, thereby improving the catalytic performance. The crystalline phases of the Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts were systematically characterized by XRD analysis, as illustrated in Fig. 2 a. Both catalysts exhibit prominent diffraction peaks corresponding to the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS 34–0394). Notably, distinct diffraction features were observed at 2θ values of 35.54° and 38.78°, which align with the (002) and (111) crystal planes of monoclinic CuO, respectively [10]. Comparative analysis reveals that the 15Cu x O/CeO2 O catalyst displays comparatively diminished peak intensities for CuO phases relative to its 15Cu x O/CeO2 C counterpart, which suggests enhanced distribution of CuO species on the surface of CeO2 O substrate. Such optimized surface architecture is anticipated to facilitate increased exposure of catalytically active sites, thereby potentially enhancing their catalytic performance in CO oxidation reactions. Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2 b) provides critical insights into lattice vibrations and defect evolution in the CeO2-based catalysts. The CeO2–O support exhibits two distinct vibrational modes: a prominent F2g band at ∼466 cm−1, characteristic of the symmetric Ce–O–Ce stretching mode in the cubic fluorite lattice, and a low-intensity feature at ∼600 cm−1, ascribed to oxygen vacancies-associated defect clusters [20]. Upon Cu x O loading, the F2g vibration demonstrates a red shift in frequency, reflecting modifications in Ce–O bond strength and force constants caused by interactions between Cu x O clusters and the CeO2 support [5]. Notably, this shift is more pronounced in 15Cu x O/CeO2–O, indicating stronger interactions between Cu x O and the CeO2 support and a weaker Ce–O bond. This decrease in Ce–O bond strength promotes the mobilization and liberation of lattice oxygen species [5]. The stronger interaction between Cu x O and CeO2 support also contribute to the generation of Vo. The proportion of Vo in the CeO2–O support is inherently greater compared to that in CeO2–C, likely due to its increased defect density (D peak located about 600 cm–1) [21]. Furthermore, this effect is significantly enhanced upon Cu x O loading, contributing to enhancing the mobility of surface-attached oxygen throughout the catalysts. Consequently, it can be inferred that 15Cu x O/CeO2–O could exhibit the better catalytic activity for CO–PROX. The structural characteristics of the synthesized Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts were evaluated through N2 physisorption measurements. The obtained adsorption-desorption profiles exhibit representative type IV curves accompanied by H3-type hysteresis in the relative pressure range of 0.5–1.0 (Fig. 3 a), indicative of a well-developed mesoporous framework [22]. This observation correlates with TEM characterization (Fig. 3 b), where 15Cu x O/CeO2–O demonstrates a distinctively porous architecture containing numerous mesoscale voids. Notably, BET surface area analysis (Table 1 ) reveals that 15Cu x O/CeO2–O possesses markedly enhanced specific surface area relative to its 15CuxO/CeO2–C counterpart. The synergistic combination of hierarchical porosity and expanded interfacial area facilitates optimal distribution of Cu x O active components, thereby generating more accessible catalytic sites for improved CO conversion efficiency. 3.2 Chemical states, local coordination environment and surface properties of the Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts The chemical speciation and defect characteristics of Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts were probed through XPS surface analysis (Fig. 4 ). Deconvolution of Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 4 a) resolved ten constituent signals, with four peaks (β: 880.7 eV, α: 884.5 eV, β′: 899.9 eV, α′: 903.2 eV) corresponding to Ce3+ states and six features characteristic of Ce4+ species [23]. Quantitative assessment derived from spectral integration (Table 1) demonstrates that 15Cu x O/CeO2–O contains elevated Ce3+ concentrations relative to 15Cu x O/CeO2–C, a finding corroborated with UV–Vis spectral features (Fig. S4) showing enhanced absorption in the 260–360 nm region [24]. This redox-active Ce3+ population promotes interfacial charge transfer through the equilibrium Cu2+ + Ce3+ ⇌ Cu+ + Ce4+ [25], while simultaneously inducing Vo formation via copper incorporation into the ceria matrix. Evaluating the concentrations of oxygen vacancies by [Vo] = 1- (3[Ce3+] +4 [Ce4+])/4, it was found that The higher content of Vo concentration in 15Cu x O/CeO2–O (Table 1), as validated by Raman spectroscopy, enhances molecular oxygen activation capacity [26], thereby optimizing catalytic performance. Deconvoluted O 1s spectra (Fig. 4 b) reveal two oxygen states: lattice oxygen (Olatt, 529.4 eV) and surface-adsorbed oxygen species (Oads, 531.7 eV) [13]. The substantial Oads component in 15Cu x O/CeO2–O (Table 1) confirms its enhanced Vo concentration compared to 15Cu x O/CeO2–C, consistent with previous defect analyses [27]. Cu 2p 3/2 spectral analysis (Fig. 4 c) distinguishes between oxidized (933.8 eV) and reduced (932 eV) copper states, with satellite/main peak intensity ratios (Isat/Imp) quantifying reduction extent [8]. The diminished Isat/Imp ratio (0.55 threshold for Cu²⁺ purity) in 15Cu x O/CeO2–O (Table 1) confirms its higher proportion of reduced copper species. Complementary Cu LMM Auger analysis (Fig. 4 d) resolves the Cu⁺/Cu0 ambiguity inherent to XPS core-level spectra [13]. The Cu LMM Auger spectral features demonstrate characteristic signatures at 918.6 eV (Cu0), 918 eV (Cu2+), and 916 eV (Cu+) [13]. The dominant Auger signal centered at ∼917.6 eV across both Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts originates from spectral superposition of Cu+ and Cu2⁺ states. These observations collectively confirm that surface-stabilized reduced Cu x O species exist primarily as Cu⁺ species in both Cu x O/CeO2 samples. From the Cu 2p XPS deconvoluted spectrum results, the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst exhibits a higher content of Cu+ species compared to 15Cu x O/CeO2–C catalyst (Table 1). The intensified Cu⁺ signal in 15Cu x O/CeO2–O correlates with its improved catalytic performance, as these reduced Cu+ centers serve as primary CO adsorption sites [8]. In addition, the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst after the CO-PROX reaction was tested by XPS. Fig. S5 shows that more CuO species were reduced into active Cu+ species during the reaction, indicating that the strong interaction between CuxO and the CeO2 support inhibited the reduction of Cu x O into Cu0 species. The synergistic combination of abundant Vo defects and stabilized Cu⁺ species establishes an optimized redox environment for efficient CO conversion. The atomic-level coordination environment of copper species in Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts was investigated through synchrotron-based XANES and EXAFS analyses. Fig. 5 a presents the Cu K-edge absorption profiles of catalyst samples alongside reference standards (metallic Cu, Cu2O, CuO), elucidating the oxidation states of copper constituents. In comparison to Cu foil, the absorption edge position of the two Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts shifts to higher energy, and located between that of Cu2O and CuO, indicating that the oxidation states of the Cu present in the Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts predominantly consist of Cu2+ and Cu+ species, consistently with the findings from XPS analysis [28]. The higher absorption-edge energy observed for 15Cu x O/CeO2 O compared to 15Cu x O/CeO2 C suggests an increased valence state of Cu species. This electronic modification could be rationalized by enhanced metal-support interaction, resulting from the optimized dispersion of Cu x O clusters at the CeO2 O interface, consistent with the findings from our prior work [5]. Analysis of the Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra (Fig. 5 b) reveals two characteristic coordination shells: the dominant peak centered at ∼1.5 Å attributable to Cu-O bonding, and a less intense feature at ∼2.5 Å corresponding to Cu-Cu interactions within the CuO framework [29]. More specifically, the diminished intensity of the next–nearest neighbor Cu-Cu coordination shell (∼2.5 Å) observed in 15Cu x O/CeO2 O compared to 15Cu x O/CeO2 C suggests a lower degree of connectivity between adjacent square-planar CuO4 moieties through edge and corner-sharing configurations, indicating an increasing dispersion of Cu x O species in 15Cu x O/CeO2 O sample. The wavelet transform (WT) analysis of the EXAFS spectra, depicted in Fig. 5 c-d, reveals intensity maxima localized at ∼4.5 Å-1 for both 15Cu x O/CeO2 C and 15Cu x O/CeO2 O catalysts, characteristic of the Cu-O coordination pathway [25]. The reducibility and oxygen dynamics of Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts were systematically examined through H2-TPR and O2-TPD analyses. H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 6 a) reveal distinct reduction behavior between catalysts: 15Cu x O/CeO2–O demonstrates bimodal reduction features at 150–260 °C, with a low-temperature feature centered at 205 °C corresponding to the reduction of highly distributed Cu x O species with a strong interaction with the CeO2 support [19], while the 230 °C signal reflects reduction of aggregated copper oxide domains with weaker CeO2 support interactions [5]. In contrast, 15Cu x O/CeO2–C exhibits a singular reduction maximum near 250 °C, confirming the MOF-derived oxygen-deficient architecture enhances Cu x O dispersion, thereby strengthening the interfacial contact between the Cu x O and CeO2. Complementary O2-TPD profiles (Fig. 6 b) resolve three oxygen evolution regimes: physical adsorption of oxygen molecules (<150 °C), activated oxygen species (O⁻/O2⁻, 150–330 °C), and lattice oxygen (O2⁻, >350 °C) [30]. The 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst demonstrates intensified desorption signals with reduced peak temperatures for oxygen vacancies-associated species (O⁻/O2⁻) compared to 15Cu x O/CeO2–C, indicating enhanced oxygen mobility–key factors in improving the CO–PROX catalytic oxidation performance. The downward shift of O2⁻ evolution temperature further confirms weakened Ce-O bonding through structural defects, aligning with Raman spectral evidence. This dual activation mechanism–simultaneous optimization of lattice oxygen mobility and molecular oxygen activation–stems from defect-mediated Cu x OCeO2 cooperativity, ultimately improving CO-PROX efficiency [31]. 3.3 Catalytic properties of Cu x O/CeO2 samples To evaluate the catalytic performance of Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts with well-dispersed Cu x O species and rich surface defect sites, CO oxidation reactions were conducted under H2-rich conditions. Comparative activity assessments (Fig. 7 a) reveal that catalysts synthesized on oxygen-deficient CeO2 (15Cu x O/CeO2–O and 25Cu x O/CeO2–O) outperform their conventional counterpart (15Cu x O/CeO2–C) in low-temperature performance. While the 25Cu x O/CeO2–O attains full CO conversion at 95 °C, the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O reaches completion at 115 °C, contrasting sharply with the 155 °C required for the 15Cu x O/CeO2–C. Notably, activity decline emerges above 195 °C for both 25Cu x O/CeO2–O and 15Cu x O/CeO2–C, suggesting thermal destabilization at elevated temperatures. Critical performance metrics (Fig. 7 b) underscore the superiority of the defect-rich 15Cu x O/CeO2–O, demonstrating T50 % and T100 % values of 72 °C and 115 °C, respectively—33 °C and 40 °C lower than those of the conventional 15Cu x O/CeO2–C catalyst. Additionally, the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O has a significantly higher TOF than 15Cu x O/CeO2 C at 75 °C (Fig. S6). This enhancement stems from the synergistic coupling of well dispersed Cu x O clusters with oxygen vacancies in the CeO2 O support, a phenomenon corroborated by structural and chemical analyses. These interactions simultaneously strengthen CO chemisorption at interfacial sites and lower the activation barrier of oxygen molecules, as evidenced by redox behavior studies. Furthermore, the optimized 15CuxO/CeO2–O catalyst maintains a broad operational window (115–215 °C) for sustained complete CO conversion. Selectivity profiling (Fig. 7 c) exposes a critical trade-off: rising temperatures above 75 °C trigger parasitic H2 oxidation. However, the 15CuxO/CeO2–O preserves superior selectivity (75–135 °C) relative to both higher Cu-loading and conventionally CeO2 supported variants, implying that engineered defects preferentially stabilize CO oxidation pathways while suppressing H2 activation. Cyclic stability tests (Fig. 7 d) confirm that the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst has an excellent reaction cyclic performance. 3.4 In situ DRIFTS measurements The interfacial reaction pathways of Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts in CO-PROX were probed via in situ DRIFTS analysis, with spectral features categorized into two characteristic domains (Fig. 8 ). Absorption bands between 1800 and 2400 cm-1 correspond to Cu+-CO adducts, while signals in the 1000–1800 cm-1 range arise from carbonate intermediates [32,33]. Both catalysts exhibit a prominent Cu+-CO vibration near 2100 cm⁻¹ (Fig. 8 a and c), confirming the critical role of Cu+ in CO chemisorption and activation. Notably, the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst displays a higher Cu+-CO peak intensity than its 15Cu x O/CeO2–C counterpart, correlating with its elevated Cu⁺ population as quantified by XRD, TEM, and H2-TPR. This abundance of Cu+ sites enhances CO adsorption capacity, directly contributing to superior catalytic performance. A temperature-dependent blue shift of the Cu+-CO vibration (2103→2108 cm-1) occurs in 15CuxO/CeO2–O (Fig. 8 b), indicative of progressively weakened Cu⁺-CO bonding at elevated temperatures [34]. Such bond attenuation facilitates rapid CO transfer and product desorption, a mechanistic advantage corroborated by intensified gas-phase CO2 signals during reaction. Apart from the CO adsorption, the defect–rich sites on the catalyst surface substantially facilitated the generation of key reaction intermediates. As shown in Fig. 8 b and d, similar vibrational peaks were observed on both Cu x O/CeO2 catalysts. The absorption band observed at 1378 cm-1 can be assigned to formate species [5], whereas the spectral features appearing around 1650 cm-1 are characteristic of bidentate carbonate structures [35]. Notably, with rising reaction temperature, the detected intensities of formate and bidentate carbonate species exhibited an upward trend, reflecting their gradual build-up across the Cu x O/CeO2 catalyst interfaces. However, the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O exhibits a weaker formate species bands compared to the 15Cu x O/CeO2–C, which suggest that the abundant defect concentrations within the catalytic surface can regulate the intermediate pathways of the catalytic reaction. In conclusion, based on the above analysis, the bidentate carbonate species could be crucial intermediate in the 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst during the CO–PROX reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, this work establishes a defect engineering approach for synthesizing Cu x O/CeO2 O catalysts through MOF-derived CeO2 O supports, achieving precise control over Cu+ site density and oxygen vacancies concentration. The optimized 15Cu x O/CeO2 O system exhibits optimal CO oxidation efficiency, attaining 100 % conversion at 115 °C with a functional temperature range spanning 100 °C. Mechanistic investigations identify dual synergistic effects driving performance: (i) the interconnected mesoporosity of CeO2 O enables well-dispersed Cu x O clusters, substantially increasing accessible Cu+ sites for CO preferential adsorption; (ii) strong interfacial electronic coupling between Cu x O and CeO2 O induces lattice oxygen destabilization, concurrently promoting oxygen vacancies generation and accelerating surface oxygen mobility. These findings validate a materials design paradigm where support nanostructuring coordinates Cu⁺-oxygen vacancy pairs to optimize both reactant activation and redox kinetics. The methodology establishes a scalable strategy for designing transition metal oxide catalysts with engineered metal-support interactions, particularly applicable to heterogeneous catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: The preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) represents a critical strategy for trace CO elimination in hydrogen purification, where CO adsorption and O2 activation are crucial for enhancing catalytic performance. Herein, we report a defect-engineered strategy mediated by MOF to promote CO adsorption and O2 activation. By pyrolyzing Ce-BDC MOF, we synthesized CeO2–O support with a high–density mesoporous structure and high surface area, facilitating the well-dispersion of CuₓO species and forming abundant interfacial Cu+ active sites. The well-dispersed Cu x O species enhance their interaction with CeO2–O, resulting in weakened Ce–O bonds and promoting both lattice oxygen activation and oxygen vacancy (Vo) formation for enhanced O2 activation. The optimized 15Cu x O/CeO2–O catalyst demonstrates exceptional catalytic efficiency, achieving complete CO conversion at a comparatively low temperature (T100 % = 115 °C), coupled with broad temperature window applicability and outstanding stability over multiple cycles. This work establishes a MOF-guided paradigm for engineering multifunctional catalytic sites, offering a generalizable approach to design high-performance oxide catalysts for hydrogen purification and beyond.
